ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: none
The class was wholly executed through virtual format.
The class was a virtual seminar format with ~10 students.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class greatly enhanced my writing ability.  Peer feedback in one-on-one meetings and around the seminar table was thoughtful and constructive.  Professor Zarin's written feedback analyzed each sentence of my writing and made me excited about revising.

how to ready essays for craft, how to use class discussion to modulate my own writing, how to effectively workshop and discuss other's writings; how to write toward a word limit; how to maintain order and clarity in increasingly longer pieces; how to be comfortable and vulnerable writing about myself.
The course developed skills in reading to better understand the structure that makes a contemporary essay successful, and then replicating it on any topic.
Insight into my strengths and weaknesses as an essayist and strategies for approaching essay writing.

The assignments are rigorous in this class! We write 5 essays, starting from 800 words to ~2,400 words (escalating in increments of 400 word counts). In the meantime, we also read two selections from the Best American Essays anthology. I learned a lot about writing to word count and other strategies: eg. setting the scene in your work, how to invite readers into your story, etc. I also worked on my peer review skills and growing comfortable with my voice + sharing my writing.

This course helped me understand how to work through a preoccupation in writing. I'm accustomed to writing arguments, but this course is less about constructing a thesis and more about attending to an idea. There are a lot of specific things I could mention, but I think the most important thing I learned was how to think about writing, and think in writing.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: the high caliber of writers (and writing feedback), workshops, written feedback from Prof. Zarin

Weaknesses: weekly essay readings outside of workshops, which felt forced and unfocused

strengths
-engaging class discussion
-frequent and expansive comments from Professor Zarin and peer reviewers
-frequent and expansive course discussion of everyone's works (we were constantly reading and workshopping each other's works, and I loved that)
-good class environment where everyone felt free to share and be vulnerable in their writing

weaknesses
-reading amount and limited ability to print materials / read offline 
- a regular mid-class break more regularly would have been appreciated

A strength of the course was Zarin's commitment to each student and willingness to work with them outside of class, and her facilitation of discussion and engagement of the group as a whole. I also enjoyed the fact that Zarin was intentional about making the group feel comfortable sharing intimate work and giving honest evaluations of other's work. A weakness was that the discussions about the essays themselves didn't seem to have much structure, and often ended up being a case of whether or not we liked the writing in general rather than an assessment of technique.

Strengths: Prof Zarin is very knowledgeable and fosters a really nice class environment even while virtual. The readings are well chosen. 

Weaknesses: The seminar is structured as discussion in the large group for the whole time without breakouts which can be a very long zoom depending on the learning style
I think the course is well done as is.

I really enjoyed the opportunity to write in a regular and rigorous way. I felt like the five assignments grew me a lot as a writer and as a person. The major strength of this class is the peer workshopping. It is super rewarding and helpful to hear from the other (talented!!) students in the class, learn from how your work registered with others, and share strategies about the creative process. 

Professor Zarin cares about this class, and she is very open about her own experiences. I know that shopping period is kind of weird now, but I would really suggest shopping the class and seeing if you like the vibe. You should know within a few classes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
This course seemed very similar to an in-person format, just on Zoom.  Professor Zarin created a safe virtual space for sharing difficult stories.  During sensitive weeks (like the election), she spent time listening to student feedback and delayed an assignment.

Hard to say how this course could have been enhanced during COVID.  Virtual learning just kind of sucks in general.

success
peer editing format
frequent in class discussion
encouragement to have mics always on to prompt more open dialogue
engagement with the comments section during class discussion
canvas thread to discuss writing and any class thoughts

improvement
two hour classes really need to be broken up. I would be okay with a longer two hour seminar actually being listed as two hours if we meant we got a 10 minute break in between (one of my two hour seminars did this and it was very very appreciated)
earlier postings of the reading so students could print materials online
We checked in at the beginning of class and took a break in the middle. I think this was successful.
I think introducing more multimedia into the course could be interesting, like video essays or something of the sort.

I think the Zoom format is extremely difficult for an intimate seminar such as this one. It is really hard to read how others are feeling and to feel safe to communicate/heard by others at times. Unfortunately, I cannot really think of a good workaround for this. I appreciated Professor Zarin integrating 5 minute breaks into classtime.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are prepared to write an essay every other week and take an onslaught of criticism in workshops, then yes, go for it!  Your writing will demonstrably improve.
Yes. I loved the workshop aspect of this course. we were always reading other's writing and that conversation was the most useful thing to me in processing how to improve my own prose.

Yes!! Prof Zarin is committed to working with every single student to develop their writing and thinking, and the class gives you space to delve deeply into whatever you want to write about. The peer environment that the professor cultivates is the best I've ever experienced, and i learnt a huge amount from editing and being edited by other students. Overall a great course that both stretched me and never overwhelmed.
Yes!! The workload is no joke with an essay basically every other week and drafts in between but your writing will definitely improve
Certainly! This was such a wonderful course and the depth of discussion and topics people wrote about really moved me. Much needed class in the midst of this pandemic!

I would recommend this course to anyone who is serious about improving their writing and being accountable to a small, intimate community of peers as they learn. I also recommend this class if one does not have too heavy of a schedule besides this course - it is really time intensive, labor intensive, and emotionally . demanding. Professor Zarin's comments are detailed and helpful. But developing a thick skin is definitely part of the experience in this class.

Yes. This course requires you to follow through with your ideas, which is often lost in courses where you write something for a deadline, and then forget about it. Peer engagement is really strong, and you get to build connections with other students who are as devoted to thought as you are. I benefited a lot from their commentary, attention and honesty.
